items.title: The Physics of Nuclear Fission
items.description: Nuclear fission releases energy when a heavy atomic nucleus absorbs a neutron and splits into smaller, more stable fragments.
items.detail:
Nuclear fission is the neutron-induced splitting of a heavy atomic nucleus into smaller nuclei. In reactor technology, uranium-235 is the isotope most commonly used.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="1">[1]</sup> A uranium-235 nucleus absorbs an incoming neutron, becomes unstable, and can split into two smaller nuclei (fission products), while releasing additional neutrons and a large amount of energy.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="2">[2]</sup> The exact products are probabilistic, but at least one neutron and energy are always released. One representative fission equation is:

$${}^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U}+{}^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n}\rightarrow{}^{141}_{56}\mathrm{Ba}+{}^{92}_{36}\mathrm{Kr}+3\,{}^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n}+Q$$

The energy first appears as kinetic energy of fragments and neutrons, then rapidly converts to heat in fuel, which is used to generate steam and electricity.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="2">[2]</sup> The source of released energy is nuclear binding-energy difference (mass defect), not a loss of nucleon count. Heavy nuclei become more stable after splitting, and the missing mass converts to energy via:

$$E=mc^2$$

Although each reaction has a tiny mass change, the large value of $c^2$ makes the energy release substantial.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="3">[3]</sup>

Nuclear waste is produced as a by-product of sustained fission and contains neutron-rich unstable nuclei that continue radioactive decay after fuel removal. Activity decreases over time as short-lived isotopes decay, while longer-lived isotopes dominate later hazards. Because waste emits both radiation and heat, shielding, cooling, and containment are essential.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="4">[4]</sup>

items.title: The Chain Reaction
items.description: A nuclear chain reaction occurs when neutrons released in one fission event trigger further fissions, allowing the reaction to sustain itself.
items.detail:
To use fission for power generation, reactions must be considered collectively in reactor fuel. Neutrons released by one fission can induce fission in nearby nuclei, creating a chain reaction.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="5">[5]</sup>

The behavior is described by the neutron multiplication factor $k$, often represented conceptually as:

$$k=\frac{N_{\mathrm{f,next}}}{N_{\mathrm{f,current}}}$$

Three regimes define reactor-state behavior:
- Subcritical ($k<1$): reaction dies out.
- Critical ($k=1$): steady, sustained reaction.
- Supercritical ($k>1$): reaction rate increases rapidly.

Sustained electricity generation requires keeping the reactor at a controlled critical state.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="6">[6]</sup>

items.title: How a Nuclear Reactor Controls Fission
items.description: A nuclear reactor controls the chain reaction by carefully regulating neutron behavior, heat removal, and fuel composition to maintain a steady critical state.
items.detail:
The primary goal of a power reactor is to maintain a sustained, controlled critical chain reaction and avoid supercritical behavior. This is a key distinction between reactors and nuclear weapons.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="7">[7]</sup>

Most conventional moderated reactors use enriched uranium fuel (typically around 4-5% uranium-235, compared with about 0.7% in natural uranium). As fission proceeds, fuel accumulates fission products and by-products; spent fuel is then removed and managed as nuclear waste.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="1">[1]</sup>

Core control components include:
- Moderator (often water or graphite): slows fast neutrons so they are more likely to induce fission in uranium-235.
- Control rods: absorb neutrons; insertion depth adjusts reactivity and keeps the reactor near $k=1$.
- Coolant (often water): removes fission heat and transfers energy to turbines for electricity generation.

Reactor systems also include shielding and reinforced containment to prevent radioactive release and protect operators and environment.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="4">[4]</sup>

items.title: Nuclear Fission in History and Safety
items.description: The development of nuclear fission moved from early experimental reactors to large-scale power generation, with major accidents shaping modern safety design.
items.detail:
Nuclear fission was discovered in the late 1930s. In 1942, the first self-sustaining chain reaction was achieved at the University of Chicago, proving that fission could be controlled and sustained.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="8">[8]</sup> This launched post-war reactor development and commercial nuclear power deployment.

Public attitudes were strongly influenced by major accidents, especially Chernobyl.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="9">[9]</sup> The Chernobyl event highlighted how reactor design details and operating decisions can interact dangerously. During a shutdown attempt, control-rod characteristics and operating conditions contributed to a rapid rise in reactivity and loss of effective chain-reaction control.

Lessons from such failures directly informed later reactor generations: removal of vulnerable design features, stronger negative feedback mechanisms, and enhanced engineered safety systems.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="7">[7]</sup>

items.title: Future Fission Technologies
items.description: Modern reactor designs introduce engineering innovations, but all remain grounded in the same fundamental physics of controlled nuclear fission.
items.detail:
Emerging technologies such as molten salt reactors and small modular reactors (SMRs) are all based on the same physical foundation: controlled fission and neutron management in the reactor core.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="10">[10]</sup>

Differences between designs are mainly engineering choices - safety architecture, scale, deployment model, thermal systems, and economics - rather than different nuclear physics.

Across all designs, safe operation still depends on maintaining a controlled, steady chain reaction.

features.headline: Renewables Energy
features.subheadline: What is a renewable energy source? United Nations defines it as ‘energy derived from natural sources that are replenished at a higher rate than they are consumed’

cards.title: 1. Solar power
cards.description: Photovoltaic cell: captures sunlight and converts it into electricity.
cards.detail:
Sunlight is composed of discrete packets of energy called photons.

More info:
- Photons have energy expressed by the formula $E = hf$, where h is Planck's constant and f is the frequency of the wave.
- Photovoltaic cells are composed of semiconductor materials such as silicon. When exposed to sunlight, electrons are dislodged from atoms and an electric current is created as electrons migrate across the cell.
- An electric field is produced by dopants added to the semiconductor crystal lattice.
- Silicon has four valence electrons; n-type dopants such as phosphorus (five valence electrons) donate weakly bound electrons and increase negative charge carriers.
- p-type dopants such as boron (three valence electrons) create greater electron attraction.
- Diffusion occurs when p-type and n-type silicon form a p-n junction; recombination and charge separation create an internal electric field and diode behavior, so current flows in one direction.
- An inverter converts the original DC current to AC current for most electrical devices.

Solar energy has variable output. In addition, the infrared part is not used to produce electricity, meaning PV cells use only part of available solar energy.

Solar energy can be converted into electricity in different ways:
- Direct conversion: voltage/current generated by photon absorption in a doped semiconductor (common for silicon solar cells).
- Thermal conversion: heat converted into electrical energy by thermionic, thermoelectric, magnetohydrodynamic devices, or steam turbines.
- Biological processes: growing crops (for example algae) and converting to methane for steam power; this route has low efficiency and requires extensive land area.

PV panels are relatively low-cost to run, and rooftop installation can have limited impact on living conditions.

references.text: U.S. Department of Energy (n.d.) Solar Photovoltaic Cell Basics.
PTO (n.d.) Photovoltaic technology overview, Vol. 25(2), p.44.
Yaqoob, S.J. et al. (2019) The potential of solar energy in diverse conversion systems.

cards.title: 2. Wind power
cards.description: Turns wind energy into kinetic energy using the aerodynamic force from the rotor blades.
cards.detail:
How do they work?

More info:
When wind flows across a blade, air pressure on one side decreases. The pressure difference across both sides creates lift and drag. Lift is stronger than drag, so the rotor spins. The rotor connects to a generator (through drivetrain components) and enables practical electricity generation.

The kinetic energy of a mass m with velocity v is:
- $E_k = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$
The air mass can be expressed using air density and swept volume.
Power is energy divided by time, and wind power scales with the cube of wind speed ($v^3$).

Since velocity is cubed, wind that is twice as fast can provide roughly eight times as much power. This is one reason turbines are tall: wind is typically faster and less turbulent at higher altitude.

Theoretical extraction is limited by the Betz limit (59.3%); in practice, turbine efficiency commonly falls in about the 34-45% range.

Design:
- Rotor blades: airfoil behavior similar to airplane wings; pressure differences cause rotation.
- Nacelle: contains gears and generator; gears raise low blade-speed rotation to generator-speed rotation.
- Tower: supports nacelle and blades at a height suitable for stronger, steadier wind (often around 50-100 m).

Wind power is becoming an increasingly popular energy choice, particularly in the UK, with major planned offshore capacity growth.

references.text: Leipzig University (n.d.) Energy fundamentals: Wind power.

cards.title: 3. Hydroelectric power
cards.description: Harnesses the power of water in motion to generate electricity.
cards.detail:
Supplies 17% of the world's energy and 71% of the world's renewable energy.

It is a flexible and reliable source of energy because output can be adjusted to demand.

More info:
Hydropower has been used for over 2000 years (for example, historical watermills). Cost of hydroelectricity is relatively low, making it competitive in many systems.

A hydro plant generally includes three parts: an electric plant (generation), a reservoir (stored water), and a dam (flow control).

Water at height stores gravitational potential energy ($U = mgh$). As water is released through a penstock, potential energy converts to kinetic energy and drives turbine blades. Turbine rotation drives the generator rotor and converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.

Hydropower also has trade-offs: river damming can disrupt ecosystems and migration routes, projects can require very high upfront cost, and some developments displace communities.

Generator physics:
- Generators convert mechanical energy into electrical energy.
- They operate on Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction.
- Electromotive force (emf) is induced when a conductor cuts a magnetic field.

Challenges:
Hydroelectric generators can face vibration and temperature-rise issues. Uneven temperature distribution can affect insulation integrity and reliability. Thermal stress during startup/shutdown can contribute to failure risk, and thermal expansion can deform stator/rotor components.

references.text: Mirzaei Mahmoud Abadi, V. et al. (2016) Hydroelectric energy: advantages and disadvantages.
Liu, X. et al. (2025) Hydropower generator operation and reliability analysis.
LibreTexts (n.d.) Electric generators and electromotive force.

cards.title: 4. Geothermal Energy
cards.description: This is the renewable energy contained as heat in the Earth’s interior. It represents 0.3% of the world’s total electrical energy.
cards.detail:
More info:

Location:
- The Earth is formed by three concentric zones: crust, mantle, and core. The crust and upper mantle form the lithosphere, split into tectonic plates.
- Geothermal resources are concentrated in areas with higher heat flow, often near plate boundaries where hot springs and steam vents appear (for example, the Pacific Ring of Fire).
- Heat also rises where crust is sufficiently thin.
- Below the crust lies hot and molten rock (magma), with heat partly produced by radioactive decay of elements such as potassium and uranium.

Geothermal energy is used directly (for example district heating) and in industry.

Geothermal power plants use hydrothermal resources from dry steam wells or hot-water wells; extracted steam/hot fluid drives turbines to generate electricity.

Geothermal plants can emit far less acid-rain-causing sulfur compounds and less carbon dioxide than similarly sized fossil-fuel plants.

Types of Geothermal Power plants:
- Dry steam plants: steam from reservoir drives turbine directly.
- Flash steam plants: high-pressure hot water is converted to steam that drives turbines; cooled condensate is reinjected.
- Binary-cycle plants: geothermal heat transfers to a secondary fluid with lower boiling point; the secondary vapor drives the turbine.

references.text: U.S. Energy Information Administration (n.d.) Geothermal power plants explained.

cards.title: 5.  Comparison of Energy Sources
cards.description: Feature comparison between Nuclear and Renewables.
cards.detail:
Feature | Nuclear | Renewables
---|---|---
Energy density | Very high | Lower
Reliability | Continuous baseload | Often intermittent
Carbon emissions | Very low | Very low
Land use | Small | Often large
Waste | Radioactive | Minimal

Societal views and impacts:
Public Perception
- Nuclear: safety, waste, and past accidents are major factors.
- Renewables: generally positive, but local objections and ecological concerns persist.

The choice between nuclear and renewables is not a simple argument. Both have roles in a zero-carbon future. Nuclear offers stable and reliable output, but with high costs and significant waste-management concerns. Renewables are among the cheapest and fastest-growing options, but still require progress in storage and grid integration. The best mix depends on each country's infrastructure, resources, and policy goals.

references.text: International Energy Agency (n.d.) Renewable electricity generation by technology, 1990-2026.
United Nations (n.d.) What is renewable energy?

safety.headline: Molten Salt Reactors (MSRs)
safety.subheadline: Fission based reactors have a massive range of different designs, each having their own advantages and disadvantages over the others. One of the most interesting and potentially advantageous of these designs is molten salt reactors. These types of reactors use molten salt within the core for a variety of purposes such as carrying the fuel or acting as a coolant or moderator, or some combination of these, and it is the molten salt that allows for significant advantages over standard reactors, while also providing major engineering challenges.

items.title: What are MSRs?
items.description: Molten Salt Reactors are a family of fission reactor designs using molten salts within the core to obtain certain significant benefits, largely unavailable to other reactor types.
items.detail:
Molten Salt Reactors are an alternative design of fission reactor to the currently used LWRs. They use molten salts, often fluoride based such as Lithium-Beryllium Fluoride, for some significant part of the reactor, such as carrying the fuel or acting as a coolant or moderator. 

They are significantly more complicated than standard reactors, requiring complicated plumbing for the salt to be properly cycled, however have massive benefits, such as increased efficiency and significantly reduced waste, over standard reactors.

There are various designs possible, using different salts, moderators, neutron speeds etc. Classifications were formalized in 2023 IAEA-TRS-489 MSR technology report[19] pg. 32. 

The 3 primary classes of MSRs are – 
- Graphite based: There is a presence of graphite in the core i.e. as a moderator. 
- Homogeneous: There are no structural materials separating the fuel salt and coolant/moderator in the core. I.e. the core is filled entirely by the fuel salt. 
- Heterogeneous: There are structural materials separating the fuel salt from the coolant/moderator. 

Other reactor designs exist outside these classes, but the majority of designs and research are encapsulated by these 3. 

Within the classes themselves, there are more sub-classes based on what salts/fuel type the reactors use etc., the below graphic from the 2024 Gen IV International Forum (GIF)[20] pg. 21 showing some of these. Other diagrams are available on page 36 and 37 of the IAEA report that goes into more detail[19].

items.title: How MSRs Work.
items.description: Molten Salt Reactors are a family of fission reactor designs using molten salts within the core to obtain certain significant benefits, largely unavailable to other reactor types.
items.detail:
Similarities to LWRs – 
MSRs are similar to standard reactors in that fissile material is placed into a reactor, undergoes nuclear fission (splitting into 2 smaller, more stable, nuclei with a small mass deficit mdm_dmd​), releasing energy (given by E=mdc2E = m_d c^2E=md​c2, assuming constant kinetic energy during the reaction), and excess neutrons that cause fission in other nuclei to continue this chain reaction until there is not enough fissile material left in the reactor, compared to the amount of other material (such as fission products, moderator or coolant), causing this chain reaction to slow and become inefficient. The energy produced is absorbed by the coolant, which is pumped through a heat exchanger, boiling water and rotating a turbine to generate electricity. (See more about standard reactors and nuclear fission on the fission page.) 

Differences to LWRs – 
The primary difference of MSRs is that, as the name suggests, molten salts have a significant role in the function of the reactor. The majority use molten salt as a solvent for the fuel, allowing it to be pumped around the system, allowing various operations such as cleaning the fuel of fission products, or using a 'freeze plug' to drain the core if the temperature gets too high. 
The mechanics and engineering behind each MSR design significantly vary due to different material choices, capability goals, fuel choice etc., but the primary benefits of these types of reactors are due to additional capabilities that standard reactors are unable to complete such as – 
- Fuel Recycling / cleaning 
- Alternative fuel sources 
- Increased Passive Safety 
- Reduced/less dangerous waste and byproducts

items.title: Recycling&Cleaning
items.description: One of the primary potential advantages of MSRs is they have the theoretical capability to use spent fuel from other reactors (or themselves) as new fuel, reducing the final amount of waste. They also can massively increase their efficiency by cleaning their fuel during usage, significantly increasing potential efficiency.
items.detail:
The majority of designs incorporate built-in chemical processing of the molten salts, removing fission products that would absorb thermal neutrons instead of fuel nuclei, meaning the reactor can work longer without needing refuelling to maintain sufficient power output and will be more efficient as fewer neutrons are wasted by being absorbed by other nuclei aside from the fuel. 

Alternative Fuel Sources – 
While MSRs still require fissile fuel, the same as LWRs, some designs include built-in breeder circuits, where non-fissile material is converted into fissile material, which is then dissolved into the salt and used as fuel. Some designs place these circuits surrounding the core, using neutrons from the fission reactions to produce more fuel for the reactions. One example is thorium-232, which upon absorbing a neutron goes through decay to uranium-233, which is fissile and used as fuel inside the core itself. Uranium-233 produces an average of 2.50±0.032.50 \pm 0.032.50±0.03 thermal neutrons per fission[21]. These neutrons are used either to continue fission or, in designs with fertile material surrounding the core, to start this decay chain again to produce more uranium. Other designs use a similar method to recycle spent fuel from other reactors and from itself, as all actinides (elements usually found in spent nuclear fuel) can be used by an MSR, either within a breeder or the core itself[20] pg. 17. 

 Increased Passive Safety – 
 MSRs have various intrinsic safety features that LWRs cannot meet due to differences in design. For example, MSRs work at near-atmospheric pressures, meaning that if components become damaged, nuclear material is significantly less likely to be dispersed over a wide area. Also, these lower pressures mean the components are under less mechanical stress and so are less likely to catastrophically fail in the first place. Another example is the properties of the salt: as it heats, it reduces the reactivity of the core, regardless of what task(s) it is performing. For example, as the salt expands with heating, the fissile nuclei are separated so fewer neutrons reach other nuclei at thermal speeds, and reactivity decreases. This gives MSRs a strong negative reactivity–temperature coefficient, providing higher core stability and allowing for passive reactor shutdown if the temperature rises too high. 

 Reduced / Less Dangerous Waste and Byproducts – 
 As mentioned, MSRs are able to make use of all actinide elements in some way or another, which are commonly found in spent nuclear fuel. This ability to use spent fuel means that the eventual waste/byproducts of MSRs are significantly less radioactive than those of other types of reactors. A consequence is that the byproducts of MSRs cannot be used as nuclear weapons at the same scale or effectiveness as LWRs or other reactors. The UK National Nuclear Laboratory produced a graphic demonstrating the closed fuel cycle that MSRs allow (MSR part in green). 

 Challenges surrounding MSRs – 
 While the base physics behind MSRs is understood and proven, their design complexity brings various engineering and technical challenges that have prevented the technology from being used on a larger scale. These challenges include – 
 - Reactor Longevity: Due to the corrosivity of molten salts, the pipes and other reactor parts are estimated to require replacement approximately every 5–7 years. 
- Fuel Cleaning: Effective removal of byproducts is a major difficulty in MSR designs. For gaseous waste, the mixture of various byproducts causes standard filters to become clogged; more effective designs must be developed to prevent build-up and the resulting decrease in efficiency over time. For solid/liquid waste, the options are either to replace the salt as a whole, massively increasing the overall waste of the reactor (open fuel cycles), or to reprocess the fuel salt either in small batches frequently or in its entirety every few years, both with technical challenges for optimising fuel use and power generation (closed fuel cycles).

sustainability.title: Green. Clean. Future.
sustainability.description: Nuclear energy has one of the smallest carbon footprints of any energy source, protecting our air quality and climate.

items.title: Efficiency
items.description: Both fossil-fuel and nuclear plants are basically heat engines. If THT_HTH​ is lower, the best efficiency you can reach is lower too.
items.detail: Both fossil-fuel power plants and nuclear power plants work the same way at a high level: you turn some fuel into heat, and then you turn that heat into electricity using a heat-engine cycle. So when we talk about "efficiency" here, it's basically how much electrical work you get out compared to how much heat you put in, and the key point is that physics puts a ceiling on it. Thermal efficiency can be written as: η=WoutQin=1−QoutQin \eta = \frac{W_{\text{out}}}{Q_{\text{in}}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{\text{out}}}{Q_{\text{in}}} η=Qin​Wout​​=1−Qin​Qout​​ The maximum theoretical efficiency for an ideal heat engine operating between a hot reservoir at temperature THT_HTH​ and a cold reservoir at temperature TCT_CTC​ is bounded by the Carnot limit: ηCarnot=1−TCTH \eta_{\text{Carnot}} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H} ηCarnot​=1−TH​TC​​ If a nuclear plant has to run at a lower hot-side temperature THT_HTH​ (because of materials and safety limits), then even in theory the best possible efficiency goes down, which helps explain why some fossil-fuel plants can look more efficient in this kind of comparison.[22]

items.title: Environmental impact
items.description: Nuclear is presented as cleaner than fossil fuels on lifecycle GHG emissions and on air pollution. Fossil-fuel power produces PM2.5/NOx/SO2, which links directly to major health impacts.
items.detail:
For greenhouse gases, the notes use a "whole life cycle" view (so not just what comes out of the chimney, but everything across the system) and point to the kind of IPCC-style tables that report gCO2eq/kWh.[23] 

 For air pollution, the fossil side is summarized pretty directly: burning fossil fuels produces PM2.5, NOx, and SO2, and for gas you also have to think about upstream methane leaks. The point being made is that these pollutants are linked to smog and acid rain, and also to respiratory/cardiovascular disease and premature deaths. In that framing, fossil-fuel electricity has a much bigger air-pollution footprint than nuclear.[24]

items.title: Safety
items.description: Nuclear routine releases are described as very low and tightly regulated, while coal ash can contain trace uranium/thorium with weaker regulation. Safety is also compared via deaths per TWh.
items.detail:
The way this section is written is basically "what people assume" versus "what the notes are trying to argue." A common assumption is that nuclear waste automatically means bigger radioactive contamination. 

 But the notes say routine radioactive releases from nuclear plants are extremely low and tightly regulated, so public radiation exposure from normal operation stays very low. On the fossil side, it highlights something people don't always think about: coal has trace uranium and thorium, and coal ash can be poorly regulated. So even though it's not "nuclear," it can still be a source of radiation exposure.[25] 

 For accidents, the notes admit nuclear accidents sound more dangerous, but argue that stricter design standards and management systems mean the accident rate is lower than for fossil-fuel power plants. There's also a more quantitative safety framing using deaths per TWh, which bundles air-pollution health impacts together with accidents. The way it's interpreted is that fossil harms are often "spread out" (lots of smaller impacts like air-pollution deaths), while nuclear risk feels like "low probability, high consequence."[24][26]

items.title: Economic cost
items.description: Fossil (esp. gas) is framed as cheap/fast to build but fuel-dominated to run, while nuclear is expensive/slow to build but cheaper to run. UK context uses official cost reports plus carbon-intensity and generation-mix data.
items.detail:
This part is written as a construction vs operation comparison. For construction, the notes describe nuclear as having a very high upfront cost and long build time, while fossil-fuel plants (especially gas) are usually faster and cheaper to build. 

 For operation, the notes flip the story: nuclear fuel is relatively cheap, so running costs can be lower than coal or gas, and that's why nuclear is framed as potentially more cost-effective over the long term even if the initial investment is huge. The cost-structure angle is also spelled out using LCOE: the LCOE of fuel power is said to be higher because fuel expenses make up a big chunk of the lifecycle cost. That's why gas plants get summarized as "cheap to build, expensive to run," and why electricity prices can jump when gas prices spike.[27]  Nuclear gets summarized as "expensive to build, cheap to run," but also sensitive to financing costs and construction delays. 

 Finally, the UK context links are there to connect this to real operation: carbon intensity changes with the short-term fuel mix, you can pull the generation mix from the Carbon Intensity API, and you can use DUKES for annual UK generation shares.[28][29][30][31]

questions.question: In a fission reaction, nucleon number is conserved. So why is energy still released?
options: Because protons are converted directly into energy
Because the fission products have greater total binding energy than the original nucleus
Because neutrons carry away energy from the nucleus
Because the uranium nucleus loses charge during the reaction
questions.explanation: The fission products are more tightly bound (higher total binding energy) than the original heavy nucleus. This increase in binding energy corresponds to a decrease in mass, which is converted into energy via E = mc^2.

questions.question: If a reactor becomes slightly supercritical (k > 1), what physically happens inside the core?
options: The number of neutrons increases exponentially with time
Uranium-235 is consumed in a single burst
Control rods stop absorbing neutrons completely
questions.explanation: When k > 1, each fission produces more than one subsequent fission on average, leading to an increasing neutron population. This causes the reaction rate and therefore power to rise.

questions.question: Why is slowing down (moderating) neutrons important in most uranium-235 reactors?
options: Slow neutrons have more kinetic energy
Uranium-235 is more likely to undergo fission with thermal (slow) neutrons
questions.explanation: Uranium-235 has a much higher probability (cross-section) for fission when interacting with slow (thermal) neutrons. Moderators increase the likelihood that released neutrons will successfully trigger further fission.

questions.question: Immediately after fuel is removed from a reactor, why is its radioactive activity initially very high?
options: Because the chain reaction is still occurring
Because many short-lived fission products are present
Because control rods are no longer absorbing neutrons
questions.explanation: Short-lived radioactive isotopes dominate the waste initially. These decay rapidly, causing high initial activity, which decreases significantly as they decay away.

questions.question: Why did the graphite-tipped control rods contribute to the rapid power increase at Chernobyl?
options: They absorbed too many neutrons immediately
They temporarily increased neutron moderation before absorbing neutrons
They removed the coolant from the reactor core
They caused uranium enrichment to increase locally
questions.explanation: The graphite tips initially increased local moderation (slowing neutrons), which temporarily increased reactivity before neutron absorption took effect, contributing to the uncontrolled rise in reaction rate.

questions.question: What is the class of an MSR that uses fluoride salts, thermal spectrum neutrons and has structural materials within the core?
What is the primary fertile material used in breeder circuits to produce fissile Uranium 233?
What is the primary benefit MSRs have over other reactor types?
options: They have a much simpler design

questions.question: What isn’t safety benefit of MSRs?
options: Passive draining through salt plugs if temperature gets too high

Fusion2.headline: What Is Fusion?
Fusion2.subheadline: Fusion is the opposite of nuclear fission, using extreme heat and pressure to fuse smaller nuclei into larger atoms.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="32">[32]</sup> This is the process that occurs within stars, hence the nickname "Star in a Jar". In order for elements to fuse, they must be superheated until all of the electrons are stripped away, and form a plasma. The nuclei then collide at such incredible speeds, the Coulomb barrier (electrostatic repulsion) is overcome, and the strong nuclear force causes the nuclei to become stable.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="34">[34]</sup> The energy from this reaction is then released as high energy neutron flux.

items.title: Confinement Types
items.description: The main properties of Inertially and Magnetically confined fusion reactors. One using Newton's Laws and extreme explosive force. The other using powerful magnets to sculpt plasma into a ring.
items.detail: There are 2 main types of confinement, inertial and magnetic. Inertial confinement uses high power lasers to generate X-rays, these X-rays ignite a fuel capsule's outer surface, generating a massive inward force.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="33">[33]</sup> Magnetic confinement generates a ring of low density plasma using magnetic fields, shaping the plasma into a torus.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="34">[34]</sup> Magnetic confinement can sustain fusion for longer amounts of time, while inertial confinement is more rapid. Common types of magnetic-confinement fusion devices include tokamaks, such as the ST40 and STOR-M. The most important inertial fusion reactor is the NIF.

items.title: Quantifying fusion
items.description: The mathematics behind how fusion is achieved. The nuclear cross section, a model for the probability of reactants fusing, and the Fusion Triple Product, a model for how effective a fusion plant is.
items.detail:
The way we quantify the effectiveness of a nuclear fusion reaction is with several values. Firstly, the nuclear cross section is a measure of the probability of 2 nuclei being able to fuse, $\sigma = R/(\Phi N)$.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="35">[35]</sup> Where $R$ is the reaction rate per unit volume, $\Phi$ is the incident particle flux and $N$ is the target density. Maximising this number (by careful choice of reactant isotopes) is necessary for achieving nuclear fusion. We also use the fusion triple product to quantify a reactor's ability to fuse. The product of temperature $T$ (MeV), plasma density $n$ (m$^{-3}$) and confinement time $\tau$ (s) is the standard value for measuring a fusion pulse.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="37">[37]</sup>

In order for fusion to be obtained at effective levels, the Lawson Criterion must be fulfilled:

$$nT\tau = 3 \times 10^{21} \text{ m}^{-3}\text{ keV}\cdot\text{s}$$

(For Deuterium–Tritium fusion).<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="36">[36]</sup> Magnetic confinement uses long pulses (theoretically hours or days) at low density to achieve this, whereas inertial confinement uses extremely high plasma density, confined for short bursts.

items.title: Fusion v Fission
items.description: Nuclear fusion has many advantages over fission, such as increased energy density, and additional safety considerations.
items.detail:
As many people are aware, the famous Chernobyl and Fukushima nuclear disasters, combined with the notoriety of the Manhattan project means that many people are afraid of nuclear energy. Nuclear fusion has many advantages to fission.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="38">[38]</sup> Fission involved moderating and controlling a violent chain reaction. However, if at any point confinement fails in magnetic fusion, the plasma cools and the reaction stops. Also, fusion facilities are operated remotely to reduce radiation exposure risk.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="39">[39]</sup> While the reactant, tritium, is radioactive (half life 12.3 years), the amount used in a fusion reactor is minuscule, and the product is helium, which is not radioactive. Neutron radiation would be harmful to human life, but while fusion reactors are active, they are operated and maintained remotely.

The binding-energy-per-nucleon graph shows the energy changes during fission and fusion. The difference in binding energy between the reactants and products is the energy released during a nuclear reaction. As you can see, the difference between a U235 fission and DT fusion is immense; the deuterium from one glass of seawater releases energy comparable to burning a barrel of oil.<sup class="ref-cite" data-ref-id="40">[40]</sup>

Fuel.title: Quick Quiz-Fossil Fuels
Fuel.description: Test Your Knowledge About Fossil Fuels

questions.question: Carnot efficiency is $\eta_{\text{Carnot}} = 1 - \frac{T_C}{T_H}$. If a nuclear plant operates at a lower hot-reservoir temperature $T_H$ than a fossil-fuel plant (same $T_C$), what happens?
options: Its maximum theoretical efficiency is lower
questions.explanation: Lower $T_H$ increases $\frac{T_C}{T_H}$, so $\eta_{\text{Carnot}}$ decreases. Efficiency depends on temperature difference.

questions.question: Why can coal power sometimes cause higher environmental radiation exposure than nuclear power during normal operation?
options: Radioactive elements concentrate in coal ash and may be less regulated
Coal only emits radiation at high temperature
questions.explanation: Uranium and thorium in coal remain after combustion and can become concentrated in ash.

questions.question: Gas power stations are described as "cheap to build but expensive to run." Why?
options: High gravitational energy of the building
questions.explanation: Fuel must be continuously burned, so operating cost depends strongly on fuel energy and price.

Renewable.title: Quick Quiz-Renewable Energy
Renewable.description: Test Your Knowledge About Renewable Energy

questions.question: What is a significant drawback of biological solar energy conversion (e.g., growing crops for fuel)?
options: It has a very low efficiency of only 1% to 2%.
It produces a DC current that cannot be inverted.
It requires a vacuum to operate effectively.
It can only be performed in spacecraft systems.
questions.explanation: Most incoming solar energy is lost as heat or reflection during photosynthesis rather than being stored as biomass. Consequently, this method requires significantly more land compared to more efficient technologies like solar panels.

questions.question: If the wind speed doubles, by what factor does the total available power increase?
questions.explanation: The power available from the wind is proportional to the cube of the wind speed (v^3). The formula for wind power is: P_wind=E_kin/Detal t = DeltaV p v^2/2Delta t = rho A v^3 / 2

questions.question: What is the "Betz limit"?
options: The maximum height a turbine tower can reach (100m).
The maximum theoretical efficiency of power extraction (59.3%).
The rotational speed required by the generator (1500 rpm).
The minimum wind speed required to start the rotor.
questions.explanation: Formulated by German physicist Albert Betz in 1919, this law proves that no turbine can capture more than 59.3% of the kinetic energy in wind. If a turbine were 100% efficient, it would stop the air entirely, meaning no more air could move through the blades to keep the turbine spinning.

questions.question: What is the name of the narrow pipe through which water is released to convert potential energy into kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: The penstock is the heavy-duty, pressurized pipe that carries water from the reservoir down to the turbine. It's designed to handle high pressure, allowing the gravitational potential energy of the water to convert into high-velocity kinetic energy to spin the turbine.

questions.question: Which country was identified as the largest producer of hydroelectricity in 2010?
questions.explanation: China has established itself as the global leader in hydroelectric power, largely due to massive infrastructure projects like the Three Gorges Dam

questions.question: What component must be used if a generator needs to produce Direct Current (DC) instead of Alternating Current (AC)?
questions.explanation: To get Direct Current (DC), a split ring commutator is used. It acts as a mechanical switch that reverses the connection to the external circuit every half-turn, ensuring the current always flows in the same direction.

questions.question: At what point is the induced emf at its maximum (peak)?
options: When the magnetic field is perpendicular to the coil.
When the angle of the magnetic field varies at its most acute point.
When the number of turns is reduced to zero.
questions.explanation: According to Faraday's Law, the induced electromotive force (emf) depends on the rate of change of magnetic flux.

questions.question: What is the primary source of the continuous heat produced in the magma layer below the Earth's crust?
options: Solar radiation absorbed by the crust.
Friction between tectonic plates in the "Ring of Fire."
The decay of naturally radioactive materials such as potassium and uranium.
The compression of hot water wells into steam.
questions.explanation: The Earth's magma layer stays hot mainly due to the decay of naturally radioactive materials such as potassium and uranium. This process, known as radiogenic heating, releases thermal energy as unstable isotopes break down into more stable forms.
